verses.text: Every friend will say, 'I am your friend,' but there are friends who are only friends in name.
verses.comment: This verse observes the difference between true and false friendship. Wisdom literature often warns against trusting in relationships too quickly.

verses.text: Is it not a sorrow unto death when a companion and friend turn into an enemy?
verses.comment: Here, we see the pain of betrayal. Compare the feelings of the Psalmist, and ultimately Jesus with Judas at the Last Supper (Matt. 26:50).

verses.text: O wicked imagination, where did you come from, to cover the earth with deceit?
verses.comment: Human nature is wounded and prone to evil intentions after the Fall (Gen. 3). This echoes the doctrine of original sin.

verses.text: A companion rejoices in a friend’s happiness, but in the time of trouble he turns against him.
verses.comment: True loyalty is tested in suffering. Scripture invites us to discern those who truly love us, as Christ loved even in suffering.

verses.text: A friend stands by a friend in battle, but hide yourself from your enemies.
verses.comment: Friendship, when genuine, is courageous. David and Jonathan's example illustrates this bond (1 Samuel 18:3).

verses.text: Faithful friends are a strong shelter; whoever finds one has found a treasure.
verses.comment: The image of a faithful friend as a shelter reminds us of the church as a spiritual refuge and community.

verses.text: All counselors praise their own advice, but some counsel is meant for their own advantage.
verses.comment: Discernment is necessary when seeking advice. Not every voice is guided by truth or charity.

verses.text: Beware of a counselor, and know beforehand what is his interest; for he will advise in his own favor, lest he lay a snare for you.
verses.comment: Even in the early church, wisdom and discernment of spirits and intentions were essential (1 Thess. 5:21).

verses.text: He will say, 'Your way is good,' but will stand at a distance to see what will happen to you.
verses.comment: Some friends only offer support when it is easy or safe. Compare this with Christ’s self-giving friendship.

verses.text: Do not consult the one who looks at you askance, and hide your intentions from those who envy you.
verses.comment: Just as Jesus often withdrew to pray alone, we are reminded to seek guidance from those who truly care for our good.

verses.text: Do not consult with a woman about her rival, or with a coward about war; with a merchant about trade, or with a buyer about selling; with an envious person about gratitude, or with the merciless about kindness; with an idler about work, or with a hired worker about the completion of business; with a lazy servant about a great task. Do not look for advice about these from such people.
verses.comment: Practical wisdom: know the limitations and prejudices of your advisors. The church cautions to discern spiritual authority and virtue in leaders and guides (see 1 Thess. 3:12).

verses.text: But rather, constantly seek a godly person, whom you know keeps the commandments, whose soul is like your own, and who will grieve with you if you fail.
verses.comment: Spiritual counsel should come from someone guided by righteousness. The community of believers strengthens the individual's walk.

verses.text: Stand by the counsel of your own heart, for no one is more faithful to you than it is.
verses.comment: Others cannot always know our innermost intentions, but God knows them, so examine your conscience in light of faith (Ps. 139:23-24).

verses.text: A man’s soul sometimes tells him more clearly than seven watchmen on a high tower.
verses.comment: There is value in interior reflection and prayer. Deep interiority—contemplation—is a mark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: And even in all this, pray to the Most High that He may direct your way in truth.
verses.comment: All wisdom should be rooted in prayer. Asking for God's guidance is foundational for discerning good counsel.

verses.text: Every work has its circumstances, and counsel depends on the right moment.
verses.comment: The wisdom of timing and prudence carries through all decisions (Prov. 15:23).

verses.text: Be very careful, for evil can lie hidden even in counsel, and in a word, there may be danger.
verses.comment: We are reminded to discern not only actions, but also words, for both can lead us toward or away from God’s will.

verses.text: A wise person will be cautious in everything; when sin is everywhere, be on guard, for discerning good and evil is not always easy.
verses.comment: The gift of discernment is vital for holiness—a key teaching in both Scripture and the lived Christian tradition.

verses.text: Sometimes a person is clever in teaching many, but useless to his own soul.
verses.comment: Teaching truth is not enough—one must live it. This is a call to authentic discipleship and personal holiness.

verses.text: A person may speak wisely to the people, yet remain useless to themselves; another is clearly detestable, but will be delivered from sin.
verses.comment: Salvation is available even to those who appear unworthy, reflecting God’s mercy.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to admit your sin, and do not strive against the current of the river.
verses.comment: Confession and humility bring healing. This verse resonates with the New Testament’s emphasis on openly confessing sin for forgiveness.

verses.text: Do not be subject to every desire, nor follow after your passions.
verses.comment: Self-mastery is a fruit of the Spirit. The life of grace involves ordering desires towards the good.

verses.text: For every desire does not bring fulfillment, neither does every path lead to what is good.
verses.comment: True happiness is found by choosing rightly, not by following every inclination.

verses.text: Do not be greedy in every bite, and do not be hasty with your food.
verses.comment: Moderation is wisdom—even concerning food. This foreshadows Christian calls to self-discipline and temperance.

verses.text: For excess in eating brings sickness, and gluttony leads to colic.
verses.comment: Physical health and spiritual health are connected in biblical teaching. All things in moderation.

verses.text: Many have died because of gluttony, but whoever controls himself prolongs his life.
verses.comment: Self-control is presented as the path to life. This virtue is emphasized throughout the New Testament.

verses.text: Be attentive to yourself and your health, for what is suitable for one person may be bad for another.
verses.comment: The teaching recognizes legitimate diversity in lifestyle and discipline, a principle affirmed within the unity of faith.

verses.text: Every appetite does not suit every person, nor does every food please everyone.
verses.comment: Individual differences are a sign of God’s providence, and unity does not mean uniformity.

verses.text: Do not eat to excess, for it will bring sickness on you.
verses.comment: This practical wisdom extends to spiritual disciplines. Fasting and moderation are means of nourishing both body and soul.

verses.text: Sickness advances because of overeating; gluttony leads to many pains.
verses.comment: The dangers of excess are not only physical; they symbolize all spiritual excess—including sin—which brings harm.

verses.text: Through moderation you will live longer and find refreshment for your soul.
verses.comment: The discipline of moderation is a recurring biblical theme: it points to the virtue, endurance, and even union with God toward which the Christian life is aimed.
